column1: In-state tuition for unauthorized immigrant students at state colleges and universities

column20: State did not have the policy

column1: Source: Julia Gelatt, Hamutal Bernstein, and Heather Koball, "State Immigration Policy Resource," Washington, DC: Urban Institute, May 2017, http://urban.org/features/state-immigration-policy-resource.

Original data sources: "Table: Laws & Policies Improving Access to Higher Education for Immigrants," in "Toolkit: Access to Postsecondary Education, National Immigration Law Center,  last modified April 2017, https://www.nilc.org/issues/education/eduaccesstoolkit2a/#tables.
"Undocumented Student Tuition: Overview," National Conference of State Legislators, accessed October 2015, http://www.ncsl.org/research/education/undocumented-student-tuition-overview.aspx.
"National Map," ULEAD Network, accessed April 28, 2017, http://uleadnet.org/issue/map.

Notes: This table indicates whether each state allows students who meet certain requirements to pay in-state tuition rates at its public colleges and universities, regardless of their immigration status.
Hawaii, Michigan, Oklahoma, and Rhode Island allow in-state tuition to unauthorized immigrant students through Board of Regents decisions.
Kentucky allows in-state tuition through its Council on Postsecondary Education's guidelines on eligibility for in-state tuition.
Virginia's attorney general issued a letter in 2014 noting that students with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) were eligible for in-state tuition in Virginia.
